Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Measurement and Modeling of Land-Atmosphere Isotopic Carbon Dioxide (CO2) Exchange in the Upper Midwest, United States
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is an improved understanding of the biophysical processes and discrimination mechanisms controlling the exchange of carbon dioxide (both 13C and 12C CO2) between the land and atmosphere at the ecosystem, landscape, and regional scales. It will focus on improved methods for measuring and modeling concentrations of trace species and fluxes in and out of the atmosphere. The approach utilizes fast tunable diode laser (TDL) measurement of isotopomer mixing ratios in combination with the eddy covariance approach for isotopic flux measurements in a heterogeneous landscape from a tall tower. The objectives are to: 1) Develop and improve micrometeorological and boundary layer methods for measuring isotopic carbon dioxide (CO2) fluxes; 2) Quantify isotopic fluxes and biophysical parameters to help understand 13CO2 discrimination mechanisms; 3) Determine the extent, rate of change, and controls on isotopic disequilibrium within a heterogeneous region in the upper Midwest, United States; and 4) Combine measurements and models to constrain key discrimination parameters at the ecosystem, landscape, and regional scales.

Undergraduate training activities will be provided in micrometeorological theory and techniques, stable isotope theory and techniques, data acquisition methods, and modeling. An intermediate undergraduate course on Land-Atmosphere Interactions will be developed and will include an intensive 2-week field component. Broader impacts also include the development of techniques for studying the impact of climate variation and land management on atmospheric CO2, assessment of the carbon sink/source potential of regions dominated by land use change, and outreach efforts including collaboration with Minnesota Public Radio.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this NSF career grant were to:

1. Develop new measurement techiques for studying the exchange of carbon dioxide and water vapor between the Earth's surface and atmosphere.

2. Improve our scientific understanding of the carbon and water cycles.

3. Examine how agricultural crops in the Upper Midwest influence carbon dioxide and water vapor concentrations in the atmosphere and the cycling of carbon and water between the land and atmosphere.

4. Develop a new course in atmospheric science at the University of Minnesota.

5. Provide state-of-the-art training for undergraduate and graduate students.

6. Disseminate new knowledge through scientific publications and presentations at scientific conferences.

 

The key project outcomes included the following:

1. Development and testing of an eddy covariance and tunable diode laser system that can measure the transport of carbon dioxide and water vapor between the land surface and atmosphere. More importantly, it can measure the isotopes ("different species") of these molecules so that researchers can trace where these molecules originated from within the carbon and water cycles.

2. Instrumented and made continuous measurements of carbon dioxide and water vapor from a very tall tower (244 m) in order to better understand how agricultural crops impact the carbon and water cycles in the Upper Midwest.

3. We demonstrated, using our isotope tracer approach described above, that corn (C4) agricultural crops account for 20 to 40% of gross photosynthetic carbon uptake within the region and have a strong influence on regional isotope discrimination. Both of these results have important implications for parameterizing and testing regional inverse modeling approaches.

4. We demonstrated that these techniques could be used to detect changes in corn production/carbon cycling in the Upper Midwest that were driven by increased demands for biofuel. 

5. New micrometeorological techniques were developed to better understand the coupling between the carbon and water cycles using the oxygen isotope tracer. A new eddy covariance and tunable diode laser system was developed specifically for measuring isotopes ("different species") of water vapor. 

6. Fostered collaboration among industry partners (Campbell Scientific), Universities (University of Minnesota, Yale University,Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology), government agencies (USDA-ARS) and provided hands on training for numerous students.

7. Developed a new course in atmospheric science (Climate Change: Myths, Mysteries, and Uncertainties) and new course content was developed for graduate courses in biometeorology.

8. Numerous peer-reviewed publications (12) and presentations (28) at scientific conferences were supported through this funding.

9. Unique datasets were made available to collaborators and the broader scientific community so that others may pursue new science questions.
